Comment: Calling it slavery is an insult to the actuial victims of slavery in the past and in the present day.  There's a concept called cost of living. Someone getting paid $4 an hour in another country is able to save or send money to their village back home. And the object of your boycott is to send the work to other countries that pay even less, so you really have no point here.  We don't have the supply chains, we don't have people willing to manufacture things. Gen Z doesn't want to work in factories.  you've moved the goalpost once. let's see you move it again with more of your "no, it's others and the best economists who are wrong" logic.

Author: JaVelin-X-

Comment: While I understand your point about the term "slavery" and the cost of living differences, it's crucial to distinguish between low wages due to economic disparity and situations where workers face coercion, lack of basic rights, and unsafe conditions. Even if $4 an hour has more relative value in another country, that doesn't negate concerns about exploitation if those wages are unfairly low or if workers are being mistreated.   The goal isn't necessarily to bring all manufacturing to the US, but to advocate for fair labor standards and ethical sourcing globally, ensuring workers everywhere have dignity and safe working environments.  Your point about the cost of living is valid, and comparing wages directly can be misleading at best, and the whole generation z does not "want to work" is a generalization at best. If corporations paid a living wage and job security, there would be no issues finding workers.
Author: _Doomer_Wojack_
